p: Individuals’ beliefs about the world and their place in it are central to most major behavioral models. The expectancy-value (EV) model ( Fishbein, 1963), the theory of planned behavior ( Ajzen, 1985), and the VBN theory ( Stern, 2000), all posit that beliefs provide the foundation from which attitudes toward objects and actions are formed, and those attitudes can be highly predictive of behaviors. It is critical to recognize, however, that beliefs may not be scientifically based and may vary substantially between individuals and groups. Indeed, “they may be irrational, based on invalid or selective information, be self-serving, or otherwise fail to correspond to reality,” but nevertheless “form the cognitive foundation for many of our responses to aspects of that world” ( Ajzen & Gilbert Cote, 2008, p. 290). This observation is particularly salient in relation to beliefs about climate change given the variance in U.S. public understanding of the phenomenon ( Maibach et al., 2009; Weber & Stern, 2011).
